uiDefinition.description: The API Key for this api

properties.description: The SpyCloud Enterprise Protection connector allows access to SpyCloud’s Enterprise Protection API. The connector is organized around the SpyCloud Enterprise Protection API endpoints. JSON is returned by all API responses, including those with errors.

info.title: SpyCloud Enterprise Protection
info.description: The SpyCloud Enterprise Protection connector allows access to SpyCloud’s Enterprise Protection API. The connector is organized around the SpyCloud Enterprise Protection API endpoints. JSON is returned by all API responses, including those with errors.

get.summary: List or Query the Breach Catalog
get.description: List or Query the Breach Catalog.
Get/Retrieve Breach Catalog Information by ID.

get.summary: Get Breach Data by Domain Search
get.description: Get Breach Data by Domain Search.

get.summary: Get Breach Data by Email Search
get.description: Get Breach Data by Email Search.

get.summary: Get Breach Data by IP Address
get.description: Get Breach Data by IP Address.

get.description: Get Breach Data by Password Search.

get.description: Get Breach Data by Username Search.

get.description: Get Breach Data for Entire Watchlist.

title.description: Breach title. For each ingested breach our security research team documents a breach title. This is only available when we can disclose the breach details, otherwise it will have a generic title.
title.title: Title

spycloud_publish_date.description: The date on which we ingested the breached data into our systems. This is the same date on which the data becomes publicly available to our customers.
spycloud_publish_date.title: Spycloud Publish Date

description.description: Breach description. For each ingested breach our security research team documents a breach description. This is only available when we can disclose the breach details, otherwise it will have a generic description.
description.title: Description

site_description.description: Description of the breached organization, when available.
site_description.title: Site Description

site.description: Website of breached organization, when available.
site.title: Site

confidence.description: Numerical score representing the confidence in the source of the breach.
confidence.title: Confidence

id.description: Numerical breach ID. This number correlates to source_id data point found in breach records.
id.title: Id

acquisition_date.description: The date on which our security research team first acquired the breached data.
acquisition_date.title: Acquisition Date

uuid.description: UUID v4 encoded version of breach ID. This is relevant for users of Firehose, where each deliverable (records file) is named using the breach UUID.
uuid.title: UUID

type.description: Denotes if a breach is considered public or private. A public breach is one that is easily found on the internet, while a private breach is often exclusive to SpyCloud.
type.title: Type

num_records.description: Number of records we parsed and ingested from this particular breach. This is after parsing, normalization and deduplication take place.
num_records.title: Number of Records

target_url.description: URL extracted from Botnet data. This is the URL that is captured from a key logger installed on an infected user's system.
target_url.title: Target Url

av_softwares.description: List of AV software found installed on the infected user's system.
av_softwares.title: AV Softwares

infected_time.description: The time at which the user's system was infected with malicious software.
infected_time.title: Infected Time

infected_machine_id.description: The unique id of the infected user's system.
infected_machine_id.title: Infected Machine Id

ip_addresses.description: List of one or more IP addresses in alphanumeric format. Both IPV4 and IPv6 addresses are supported.
ip_addresses.title: IP Addresses

user_sys_registered_owner.description: System registered owner name. This usually comes from Botnet data.
user_sys_registered_owner.title: User System Registered Owner

keyboard_languages.description: The keyboard language found in the OS. This usually comes from Botnet data.
keyboard_languages.title: Keyboard Languages

user_hostname.description: System hostname. This usually comes from Botnet data.
user_hostname.title: User Hostname

user_os.description: System OS name. This usually comes from Botnet data.
user_os.title: User OS

infected_path.description: The local path to the malicious software installed on the infected user's system.
infected_path.title: Infected Path

source_id.description: Numerical breach ID. This correlates directly with the id field in Breach Catalog objects.
source_id.title: Source ID

spycloud_publish_date.description: The date on which we ingested the breached data into our systems. This is the same date on which the data becomes publicly available to our customers.
spycloud_publish_date.title: Spycloud Publish Date

email_domain.description: Domain extracted from 'email_address' field. This is not a SLD, but everything after the '@' symbol.
email_domain.title: Email Domain

email_username.description: Username extracted from 'email' field. This is everything before the '@' symbol.
email_username.title: Email Username

severity.description: Severity is a numeric code representing severity of a breach record. This can be used in API requests to ensure only Breach Records with plaintext password are returned.
severity.title: Severity

document_id.description: UUID v4 string which uniquely identifies this breach record in our data set.
document_id.title: Document ID

password_plaintext.description: The cracked, plaintext version of the password (where the password is crackable).
password_plaintext.title: Password Plaintext

password_type.description: Password type for original password as found in the data breach. This will either be plaintext or one of the many password hash/encryption types (SHA1, MD5, 3DES, etc).
password_type.title: Password Type

target_url.description: URL extracted from Botnet data. This is the URL that is captured from a key logger installed on an infected user's system.
target_url.title: Target URL

ip_addresses.title: IP Addressess

infected_machine_id.title: Infected Machine Id

infected_time.title: Infected Time

user_sys_domain.title: User System Domain

Infected_Machine_Id.name: infected_machine_id
Infected_Machine_Id.description: One or more comma delimited Infected Machine ID to search for compass breach records.

Target_Application.name: target_application
Target_Application.description: One or more comma delimited Compass target application (subdomain or domain) to search for.

ID.name: id
ID.description: Numerical ID of the breach. Both integer and UUIDv4 ID formats are supported. You may also use a comma delimiter to request more than one breach at a time.

Domain.name: domain
Domain.description: Domain or Subdomain name to search for.

IP.name: ip
IP.description: IP address or network CIDR notation to search for. For CIDR notation, use an underscore instead of a slash.

Password.name: password
Password.description: Password you wish to search for.

Username.name: username
Username.description: Username you wish to search for.

Query.name: query
Query.description: Query value to search the breach catalog for.

Type.name: type
Type.description: This parameter lets you filter results by several types. The allowed values are 'corporate' for corporate records, and 'infected' for infected user records, email_domain to just match against email domains, and target_domain to just match against target domains or subdomains. If no value has been provided the API function will, by default, return all record types.

Compass_Type.name: type
Compass_Type.description: This parameter will return records that are verified or unverified, meaning those that matched the watchlist or not. By default if type is not used, both types will be returned.

Watchlist_Type.name: watchlist_type
Watchlist_Type.description: This parameters lets you filter results for only emails or only domains on your watchlist. The allowed values are: ['email', 'domain', 'subdomain', 'ip']. If no value has been provided, the API will return all watchlist types.

Cursor.name: cursor
Cursor.description: Token used for iterating through multiple pages of results.

Since.name: since
Since.description: This parameter allows you to define the starting point for a date range query on the spycloud_publish_date field.

Until.name: until
Until.description: This parameter allows you to define the ending point for a date range query on the spycloud_publish_date field.

Since_Modification_Date.name: since_modification_date
Since_Modification_Date.description: This parameter allows you to define the starting point for a date range query on the when an already published record was modified (record_modification_date).

Until_Modification_Date.name: until_modification_date
Until_Modification_Date.description: This parameter allows you to define the ending point for a date range query on the when an already published record was modified (record_modification_date).

Severity.name: severity
Severity.description: This parameter allows you to filter based on the numeric severity code.

Source_Id.name: source_id
Source_Id.description: This parameter allows you to filter based on a particular breach source.

Salt.name: salt
Salt.description: If hashing is enabled for your API key, you have the option to provide a 10 to 24 character, high entropy salt otherwise the pre-configured salt will be used.

Since_Infected.name: since_infected
Since_Infected.description: This parameter allows you to define the starting point for a date range query on the infected_time..

Until_Infected.name: until_infected
Until_Infected.description: This parameter allows you to define the ending point for a date range query on the infected_time field.
